Scheme 1 Fig. 1 Molecular structure of [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2. Displacement ellipsoids are shown at the 50 % probability level. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 X-ray powder diffraction patterns of [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 and its derived catalyst (λ = 0.9699 Å). A pattern calculated from the single-crystal diffraction data for [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 is also shown. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 X-ray powder diffraction of catalyst NiWS-tfs. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Ni K-edge XANES spectra (left) for [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 and its derived catalyst NiWS-tfs compared to reference NiS and NiO and Fourier transforms of EXAFS spectra (right) for the same four samples: experimental data. Local structure parameters corresponding to the theoretical curve are given in Table 1 (for non-linear curve fitting results, see Figs. S1 and S2). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 W L3-edge XANES spectra (left) for [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 and its derived catalyst NiWS-tfs compared to reference WO3 and WS2 and Fourier transforms of EXAFS spectra (right) for the same four samples: Local structure parameters corresponding to the theoretical curve are given in Table 2 (for non-linear curve fitting results, see Figs. S3 and S4). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Micrograph of the NiWS-tfs catalyst obtained on the basis of [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 TEM micrographs of the catalysts obtained on the basis of [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 in the first (a), fifth (b) and sixth (c) cycles of use. Graphical abstract The unsupported NiWS-catalyst was obtained from the precursor [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 in a hydrocarbon medium (in situ) for hydrogenation bicyclic aromatic compounds. The precursor [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 and the catalyst prepared on its basis were studied by the X-ray diffraction and X-ray absorption methods, XPS and TEM. It was found that the new catalyst formed in situ contains tungsten sulfide and nickel sulfide nanophases. Tungsten sulfide, which has a layered structure, partially forms an insertion compound with nickel that enters between the WS2 layers and bonds covalently to sulfur. The proposed catalyst has proved to be active in the hydrodearomatization processes of model aromatic compounds (naphthalene, methylnaphthalenes) and exhibited the maximum selectivity with the formation of decalins compared to other earlier studied catalysts formed from other precursors in the reaction medium. Keywords Nickel-tungsten sulfide catalysts Unsupported catalysts Nanocatalysis 1 Introduction The ongoing reduction in light oil resources necessitates the processing of heavier petroleum fractions characterized by a higher content of aromatic hydrocarbons (HC) and sulfur-containing compounds. The necessity of processing heavy petroleum feedstocks leads to studying new oil hydrofining catalysts that are resistant to sulfur deactivation. Catalysts based on tungsten and molybdenum sulfides are widely used in the modern oil processing industry [1]. The W- and Mo-containing catalysts prepared on supports are characterized by resistance to catalyzer poisons and effective in hydrodearomatization and hydrodesulfurization of petroleum fractions. The Ni–Mo-, Co–Mo-, Ni–W and Co–W-containing compositions are studied the most. The Ni and Co transition metals contained in them are used in small amounts and perform the function of promotors, which considerably improves the catalytic properties of sulfides [2–5]. Currently there is a trend towards waiving the use of supports in the synthesis of sulfide catalysts. This step leads to manufacture of fine dispersed catalysts directly in an HC feedstock (in situ). Unsupported nanocatalysts can be used in slurry reactors, and they surpass conventional reactors in the catalytic activity [6]. The structure of promoted sulfide catalysts was studied in detail by the high-resolution electron microscopy method [7–9]. According to present-day views, active sites are located at the edges of tungsten or molybdenum sulfide nanoparticles. Ni or Co promoters interact with WS2 and MoS2 edge atoms and thus change the composition and structure of active sites. However, a high content of nickel in bulky unsupported systems results in the fact that Ni or Co can be localized not only at the edges of sulfide layers, which requires additional studies of the composition and structure of unsupported sulfide catalysts. The properties of unsupported catalysts depend on the precursor nature and the environment where their synthesis proceeds. Changes in the precursor nature result in changing the properties of catalysts and, first of all, their activity and selectivity. Such precursors as thiosalts that contain tungsten and nickel are of particular interest for the hydrodearomatization and hydrodesulfurization processes [10–13]. The best known examples are ammonium-containing precursors [14–17], for which it has been found that the presence of nitrogen atoms interferes with the formation of the sulfide phase and reduces the number of catalytically active sites. Earlier we studied catalysts prepared by thermal decomposition of 1-butyl-1-methylpiperidinium nickel thiotungstate precursor [BMPip]2Ni(WS4)2 [18], suspension of Ni/(NH4)2WS4 precursor solids in an HC feedstock [19] and oil-soluble tungsten hexacarbonyl precursor W(CO)6 [20], for which nickel (II) 2-ethylhexanoate Ni(C7H15COO)2 was used as a nickel source. The thiosalt cation nature can be substantially modified, which inevitably implies changes in the catalyst properties. In this paper, we have researched the triphenylsulfonium nickel-thiotungstate precursor [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 first synthesized by us [21,22]; we have also studied its structure and the properties of the catalyst prepared on its basis. Precursor [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 contains no nitrogen atoms, while carbon is only included in a sufficiently stable phenyl radical (unlike, for example, precursor W(CO)6). As a result, a considerably lower content of carbon can be expected on the surface of the respective catalyst. As follows from the empirical formula, thiosalt [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 contains sulfur both in cation [Ph3S]+ and in anion [Ni(WS4)2]2−, which is an important feature distinguishing it from other precursors. It is to be expected that a high sulfur content will result in a greater degree of catalyst sulfiding, which will positively affect its catalytic properties. In this paper we used the X-ray diffraction and X-ray absorption methods, XPS and TEM, and studied the properties of the catalyst prepared by the decomposition of thiosalt [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 in the reaction media in the model hydrocarbon hydrodearomatization processes in detail. Naphthalene and methylnaphthalenes were used as a feedstock. The studied catalyst is a system of stable nanoparticles dispersed in the reaction medium. 2 Experimental 2.1 Precursor and catalyst synthesis procedures The precursor triphenylsulfonium nickel-thiotungstate [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 was prepared by the following method. A solution of nickel chloride hexahydrate containing 0.12 g of NiCl2·6H2O (Aldrich, ≥98 %) and 7 mL of a H2O–CH3CN mixture (a volume ratio of H2O:CH3CN = 1:2.5) was added to a solution containing 0.35 g of ammonium thiotungstate (NH4)2WS4 (Aldrich, ≥99.9 %) and 13 mL of a H2O–CH3CN mixture (a volume ratio of H2O:CH3CN = 1:1.4). A solution containing 2.0 g of [Ph3S]CF3SO3 (Aldrich) and 7.5 mL of CH3CN was added to the resulting mixture through a drop funnel. The formed brown precipitate was filtered off, washed with water and diethyl ether, and then dried in the air. Unsupported catalyst was prepared in situ by the decomposition of precursor [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 directly in an HC feedstock [21]. The formation of the catalyst took place in the course of a catalytic reaction under process conditions (T = 350 °C, PH2 = 5.0 MPa, 5 h). The catalyst prepared on the basis of [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 was designated as NiWS-tfs. The earlier studied catalysts were designated as NiWS-bmp (on the basis of [BMPip]2Ni(WS4)2 [18]), NiWS-wsp (on the basis of Ni(NO3)2/(NH4)2WS4 [19]) and NiWS-osp (on the basis of tungsten hexacarbonyl and nickel (II) 2-ethylhexanoate [20]). Specific surface areas for the in situ obtained catalysts are (m2/g) 33.6 (NiWS-bmp), 25.3 (NiWS-wsp), 41.2 (NiWS-osp) [23] and 26 (NiWS-tfs)|. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction patterns for catalysts were obtained using a Rigaku Rotaflex RU-200 rotating-anode X-ray machine equipped with a D/Max-B wide-angle horizontal goniometer. The anode material is copper; the wavelength of copper Kα radiation is λ = 1.542 Å; Kβ radiation was absorbed by a nickel filter. The X-ray pattern was recorded using a scintillation detector. Patterns were taken according to the Bragg-Brentano scheme in the θ-2θ geometry within the angular range of 5–115 degrees (by 2θ) by means of scanning in increments of 0.02 degree and at a rate of 1 degree per minute. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 were collected at the ‘Belok’ beamline (λ = 0.96990 Å) of the Kurchatov Synchrotron Radiation Source [24]. Single crystals suitable for analysis were picked out from nominal polycrystalline powder without a dedicated crystal growth stage. The dataset was collected at 100 K. In total, 720 frames were collected with an oscillation range of 1.0° in the φ scanning mode using two different orientations of a crystal. The data were indexed and integrated using the utility iMOSFLM from the CCP4 software suite [25]. The semiempirical correction for absorption was applied using the Scala program [26]. The structures were solved by intrinsic phasing modification of direct methods [27] and refined by a full-matrix least-squares technique on F2 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms and hydrogen atoms involved in H-bonding. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined within the riding model with fixed isotropic displacement parameters. All calculations were carried out using the SHELXTL program. For details, see Table S1 in Supporting Information. X-ray powder diffraction patterns for [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 were measured at the same beamline and wavelength in the transmission geometry at room temperature. Ni K-edge and W L3-edge XANES/EXAFS spectra for [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 and its derived catalyst were measured at the Structural Materials Science beamline of the Kurchatov Synchrotron Radiation Source [28]. The spectra were measured in the transmission mode at room temperature using ionization chambers filled with N2/Ar mixtures providing 20 % and 80 % absorption for I0 and It, respectively. For the sake of comparison, X-ray absorption spectra of several relevant reference compounds, including NiO, NiS, WO3, and WS2 (nanostructured powder used as a support for catalysts), were measured under identical conditions. Standard data processing was performed using Athena and Artemis programs of the IFEFFIT suite [29] with FEFF [30] ab initio photoelectron amplitude and phase functions. Electron microscope images of the samples were obtained using a Hitachi TM3030 desktop scanning electron microscope. Before imaging by the vacuum deposition method, a gold layer was deposited on the surface of the samples. The information on the local composition of elements and the distribution of elements on the sample surface was obtained using an add-on energy dispersive spectrometer with a Quantax 70 EDS system. The structure and morphology of the catalyst samples were studied using a JEOL JEM 2100 analytical electron microscope composed of a base transmission electron microscope (TEM) for recording electron microscopic images and electron diffraction patterns, a computer control system with an integrated scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) image observation device, and an energy dispersive X ray spectrometer (JED 2300). The distribution of the sulfide particles with respect to particle length and the number of layers in multilayer agglomerates was derived from the statistical estimation of sizing features of more than 300 particles of the active component in different TEM images for each catalyst. Based on the statistical analysis conducted after the processing of micrographs, the average length of the sulfide particles ( L ¯ ) and the average number of layers ( N ¯ ) were determined. Considering that the formed particles have a hexagonal shape, the geometric characteristics of the sulfide phase were calculated by the method proposed in [31]: the number of W atoms along one side of the WS2 crystallite ( n i ) , the number of W atoms located at the WS2 crystallite edges ( W e ) , the number of W atoms located at the WS2 crystallite corners ( W c ) , the total number of W atoms in the average WS2 particle ( W T ), dispersity of particles (D). (1) L ¯ = ∑ l i n (2) N ¯ = ∑ N i n i n (3) n i = 10 · L ¯ 3,2 + 1 2 (4) W e = ( 6 · n i - 12 ) · N ¯ (5) W c = 6 · N ¯ (6) W T = ( 3 · n i 2 - 3 · n i + 1 ) · N ¯ (7) D = W c + W e W T X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies of the catalyst samples were conducted on a Physical Electronics ESCA PHI-5500 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. Photoemission was excited using 300 W nonmonochromotized Al Kα radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV). The powders were pressed in an In plate. The diameter of the analyzed area was 1.1 mm. Photoelectron peaks were calibrated against the carbon C 1s line with a binding energy of 284.9 eV. Deconvolution of the spectra was conducted by non-linear least-square method using the Gaussian-Lorentzian function. We determined the relative concentrations of each species NiS, Ni–W–S, WS2 etc. for every catalyst. As example, the relative amount of Ni–W–S (%): (8) [ N i – W – S ] = A N i - W - S A N i - W - S + A N i S + A N i O × 100 (9) [ W S 2 ] = A W S 2 A W S 2 + A W O 3 + A W O x S y × 100 where A M is the peak area of M species. The effective content of the Ni–W–S phase on the catalyst surface (CNiWS) was calculated from the equation: (10) C N i W S = N i W S · C N i 100 , where [NiWS] is the relative Ni concentration in the Ni–W–S phase, %; CNi is the content of Ni atoms on the catalyst surface determined by the XPS method, at. %. The effective content of the WS2 phase on the catalyst surface (CWS2) was calculated from the equation: (11) C W S 2 = W S 2 · C W 100 , where [WS2] is the relative W concentration in the WS2 phase, %; CW is the content of W atoms on the catalyst surface determined by the XPS method, at. %. The promoter ratio of WS2 crystallites with W atoms, (Ni/W)tot, was determined from the equation: (12) ( N i / W ) t o t = C N i W S C W S 2 . 2.3 Catalytic tests and product analysis The catalytic hydrogenation reactor was a steel autoclave, where the precursor and 10 wt % of the substrate solution in n-hexadecane were placed. After that, the autoclave was filled with hydrogen to a pressure of 5.0 MPa and held at a temperature of 350 °C for 5 h. The hydrogen:W ratio was varied from 500:1 to 10.5:1. Among model substances, naphthalene, 1- and 2-methyl naphthalenes were used. The reaction products were analyzed on a Crystallux 4000 M chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector and an SPB-1 capillary column coated with the polydimethylsiloxane stationary liquid phase. The column length was 30 m; the capillary internal diameter, 0.25 mm; carrier gas, helium; split ratio, 1:90. Chromatograms were processed using the NetChromWin software program. Catalyst regeneration was carried out as follows: for each cycle, the derived product was separated by centrifuging, then dried out in inert gas flow, then placed in the reactor again, after which feedstock was added and the above procedures were repeated. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Crystal structures of [Ph3S]2[Ni(WS4)2] According to Cambridge Structural Database, only a few crystal structures with the nickel bis(tetrathiotungstate) bianion have been reported so far. Essentially, salts with [AsPh4]+ [32] and [PPh4]+ [33] cations were published. The former was measured and refined against room temperature data, whereas the latter was solved from powder data. Triphenylsulfonium is also a quite rare cation. In overall, about ten crystal structures with such a moiety have been reported so far. As examples of such structures, salts triphenylsulfonium bromide mono hydrate, triphenylsulfonium azide [34], and triphenylsulfonium tetrafluoroborate [35] can be mentioned. The molecular structures of [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 along with the atom numbering scheme and selected bond lengths and angles are shown in Fig. 1 . The complex is crystallized in the monoclinic syngony, space group P21/n. Both the [Ni(WS4)2]2− dianion and triphenylsulfonium cations occupy general positions. Nickel atoms in the structure adopt distorted square planar coordination formed by sulfur atoms with the mean Ni-S bond length of 2.247 Å. The environment of W atoms in the tetratungstate moieties is tetrahedral. The mean WS bond length with the terminal sulfur atoms is 2.164 Å and the respective mean bridging W S bond length is 2.239 Å. The distance between Ni and W atoms in the structure is 2.82–2.83 Å. 3.2 Results of X-ray powder diffraction of [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 Powder diffraction patterns of [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 and its derived catalyst are shown in Fig. 2 . This figure also shows a diffraction pattern calculated from crystallographic data. Despite the fact the single-crystal X-ray study was performed at 100 K and powder diffraction pattern was measured at room temperature, they essentially similar. This means that the sample is strictly single-phase, It is stable against storage in ambient atmosphere without severe precautions. Furthermore, this means that the [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 structure does not experience phase transitions upon cooling from room temperature to 100 K. 3.3 Results of X-ray powder diffraction of catalyst NiWS-tfs As previously established [18,20], according to X-ray powder diffraction data the catalysts NiWS-bmp and NiWS-osp contain two nanocrystalline phases identified as Ni9S8 and WS2. The catalyst prepared from [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 contains no well crystalline phases (Fig. 3 ). Its diffraction pattern reveals a series of strongly broadened peak corresponding to coherent scattering lengths 2.5–3.0 nm both along the crystallographic axis c and within the ab plane (as estimated by the Scherrer equation from integral widths of 002 and 110 peaks, respectively). Positions of the diffraction peaks fairly correspond to those in 2H-WS2 modification. In particular, the position of 002 peak corresponds to the interplanar distance of 6.45 Å, which is by 0.2 Å larger than in well crystalline WS2. No crystalline Ni-containing phase could be identified. 3.4 Results of X-ray absorption spectroscopy Ni K-edge XANES and EXAFS spectra are shown in Fig. 3. The near-edge spectrum of [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 reveals a set of rather broad maxima at 8339.6 eV, 8348 eV, and 8362.6 eV in a general agreement with the square planar coordination environment formed by sulfur atoms. The spectrum of the catalyst is similar to that of [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 in terms of general shape and positions of main spectral features but it is more smeared. Furthermore, positions of the main XANES peaks are different from those in the reference compound NiS, which is characterized by the octahedral coordination of Ni atoms. Presumably, this means that the square planar sulfide environment is inherited in the catalyst from its crystalline precursor except for the introduction of some disorder. The local structure parameters around Ni atoms in [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 according to a quantitative analysis of EXAFS spectrum (Table 1 and Figs. S1 and S2 in Supporting Information) are very similar to expected ones from crystallographic data. A good fit can be obtained using a structural model including Ni-S contacts with the coordination number of 4, Ni…W contacts with the coordination number of 2, and longer photoelectron scattering paths Ni…S as well as multiple scattering contributions (see Table 1). In the case of the catalyst, only one Ni-S contribution with a similar coordination number as for the precursor and nearly the same Ni-S bond length is sufficient to reproduce the experimental curve. W L3-edge XANES and EXAFS spectra are shown in Fig. 4 . The spectra of crystalline precursor and its derived catalyst are similar but not identical. The maximum of X-ray absorption coefficient in both spectra is located at 10,205 eV as well as in the reference nanostructured WS2. The prominent absorption maximum (so-called white line) has a shoulder at a higher-energy side at 10,213 eV. The intensities of the main absorption maximum and the shoulder in the case of catalyst occupy an intermediate position between [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 and WS2 . The first EXAFS wiggle is observed at 10,267 eV, 10,254 eV, and 10,252 eV for [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2, WS2, and catalyst, respectively. A more accurate interpretation of changes with the local environment of W atoms on going from [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 to the catalyst can be achieved from quantitative EXAFS analysis (Table 2 ). As in the case of Ni K-edge spectrum, the local structure parameters around W as derived from W L3-edge spectra are very close to anticipated crystallographic values. In the catalyst, the WS bond length and coordination number corresponding to the first-coordination-sphere increase implying a change in the type of the coordination polyhedron. Most probably, the tetrahedral coordination typical of [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 is changed into trigonal prismatic or octahedral one. Two latter coordination types are observed in particular in polymorphs of WS2. Furthermore, peaks of more distant interatomic contacts in the EXAFS spectrum of the catalyst are reliably described by W⋯W and W⋯S contributions at distances similar to those in WS2. The introduction of additional W…Ni contact further improves the fit (see Table 2, Models 1 and 2, respectively). Therefore, on the basis of all experimental data observed we suggest that the nanocrystalline catalyst prepared from [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 can be regarded as a ternary sulfide, or an intercalation compound with approximate stoichiometry NixWS2 (x = 0.1−0.5) with nickel atoms located in the van der Waals space between WS2 sheets forming covalent Ni-S bonds probably also containing a fraction of amorphous Ni sulfide species. The local environment of nickel atoms is rather irregular and close to the square planar one. The local environment of tungsten atoms resembles that in crystalline WS2 (Fig. 5 ). Similar structures we postulated in a number of related systems. In particular, thermolysis of Ni(OH)2/MoS2 obtained via the interaction of single-layer dispersion of MoS2 with hydrated Ni2+ ions afforded a ternary sulfide NixMoS2 with structural parameters (including powder pattern, set of Ni-S and Mo-S distances from EXAFS) similar to the reported catalyst prepared from [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 [36]. 3.5 Electron microscopy study Studying a NiWS-tfs sample by the scanning electron microscopy method has demonstrated that the catalyst is smooth particles containing large ball-shaped cavities of 5−10 μm in size (Fig. 6 ). This means that the formation of catalytically active phase in an HC feedstock is accompanied by active gas evolution in the course of precursor decomposition. Analysis of the composition of elements has shown regular distribution of W, Ni, S, C and O elements on the catalyst surface. Unlike NiWS-tfs, the prior electron microscopy study of NiWS-bmp and NiWS-osp samples has demonstrated that catalyst particles have a size of 5−80 μm, do not contain cavities and are covered by small particles of 0.5–1.0 μm in size. Cleavages of the particles are smooth and do not contain small particles thereon [18,20]. According to the X-ray phase analysis, the NiWS-tfs sample has the highest dispersity (the smallest particle size). We associate this with a greater decomposition rate of the respective precursor. Thermal decomposition of [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 is accompanied by intensive gas generation that results in the formation of cavities not found in the micrographs for two other samples. Thus, the NiWS-tfs catalyst is considerably different from the samples studied earlier, in terms of both particle shapes and chemical composition of the surface. The nickel-tungsten sulfide catalyst NiWS-tfs was studied by the high-resolution TEM method (Fig. 7 ). Well-defined threads being the ends of the WS2 layers are visible in the micrograph. The layers are grouped into stacks that present tungsten sulfide phase domains. The domains are differently directed, their forming layers are curved, which, according to [8], results in defectiveness of the tungsten sulfide phase. In addition, poorly resolved threads that pertain to the nickel sulfide (similar to described in [18,20]) can be seen in the TEM micrographs. As a result, we observe mixed phases of tungsten sulfide and nickel sulfide. The size of tungsten sulfide phase domains is considerably smaller than the size of nickel sulfide phase domains, in terms of both the length and the number of layers. The X-ray phase analysis data confirm the conclusion that the size of WS2 and Ni9S8 phases in the studied catalysts is substantially different. The above results of studying the precursor [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 and the corresponding catalyst NiWS-tfs by different physical methods allow drawing a conclusion about the active component structure. Literature data [31,32] are indicative of the fact that a tungsten sulfide-based catalyst promoted with nickel has a layered structure, where a layer of tungsten atoms is surrounded by two layers of sulfur atoms. The SW S layers bound by the Van der Waals bonds between the adjacent sulfur layers and forming the WS2 phase domains are visible in the micrograph (Fig. 7a). Despite the fact that the studied catalysts contain the nickel sulfide phase, the edge atoms of the tungsten sulfide phase domains, where the nickel atoms are localized, are active sites [9]. Based on the X-ray absorption spectroscopy results, this paper shows that nickel forms not only a surface compound, but also an insertion compound with tungsten sulfide. Nickel atoms are located between the WS2 layers and find themselves in the distorted square-planar surrounding of sulfur atoms, thus forming covalent bonds. Insertion of nickel in this case can change the distance between the tungsten sulfide layers and should have influence on the structure of active sites. 3.6 Hydrogenation of naphthalene Activity of NiWS-tfs was compared with activity of the earlier studied catalysts [18–20], in the presence of which the naphthalene conversion degree is 92–100 %. The study was conducted at a temperature of 350 °C and the naphthalene to tungsten molar ratio of 10.5:1. The maximum formation of decalins is observed in the presence of the NiWS-tfs catalyst prepared by decomposition of the new precursor [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 (63 %), while for NiWS-bmp this value is 20 %, for NiWS-osp it is 15 %. The activity of the NiWS-wsp catalyst in the same conditions is even lower: the total conversion of naphthalene does not exceed 40 %. The main reaction product is trans-decalin that is more thermodynamically stable. The ratio between cis- and trans-decalins is 1:2.6. The naphthalene to tungsten molar ratio also affects the NiWS-tfs catalyst activity. When the ratio changes from 500:1 to 105.3:1 (with the reaction time of 5 h), the naphthalene conversion rises from 35.0 % almost to 100 % and further remains equal to approximately 100 % up to the naphthalene to tungsten ratio of 10.5. With the molar ratio of 500:1, the main product is tetralin (69.4 %); however, as tungsten increases in the feedstock, the share of tetralin in the reaction products drops, and when the ratio is 10.5:1, it is equal to 12.2 %. The reason for high activity of the NiWS-tfs catalyst appears to lie in the fact that its composition differs substantially from other samples. The XPS method has demonstrated that the carbon content in the NiWS-tfs is only 24.4 %, while it exceeded 40 % in the earlier studied catalysts [18–20]. Moreover, the sulfur content on the surface of the studied catalyst (34.8 %) considerably exceeds the sulfur content in the comparison catalysts (not more than 25 %) [18–20]. Evidently, this results in a higher content of the active sites and, consequently, in the rise of catalytic activity. A low carbon content can be due to the fact that the phenyl radical generated upon decomposition of the [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 precursor is more stable and interacts with tungsten and nickel forming carbon-containing compounds at a lower rate than decomposition products, such as [BMPip]2Ni(WS4)2 or W(CO)6 and Ni(C7H15COO)2. This is confirmed by the SEM results (Fig. 6), where cavities indicative of a high gas evolution rate during decomposition of [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 are visible in the micrograph, which is not observed for other precursors. A high sulfur content in the NiWS-tfs is obviously related to the fact that sulfur in the precursor is contained both in cation and in anion, which leads to its high content on the catalyst surface. The above results testify that the nature of the precursor has an essential influence on the properties of nanoscale NiWS-sulfide catalysts and, above all, on their catalytic activity. 3.7 Restudy of catalyst properties in the naphthalene hydrogenation reaction The studies of the catalytic activity after ten regeneration cycles and re-use have shown that the conversion degree remains almost unchanged at 97.6–100%. Meanwhile, the process selectivity changes, namely, the content of decalins in the reaction products decreases. Introducing 2.5 wt % of a supplementary sulfur additive (the 6th cycle) leads to the increase in the content of decalins and to subsequent reduction in their conversion degree (Fig. 8 ). Samples obtained after the first, fifth and sixth cycles were studied by the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) methods. It can be seen in the TEM micrographs (Fig. 7b, c) that the catalyst has a layered structure typical for NiWS catalysts [18–20]. The main characteristics derived from the TEM data are presented in Table 3 . As can be seen from the table, the average length of crystallites (and other characteristics) increases from the 1 st to the 5th cycle and then slightly decreases after the introduction of elemental sulfur to the reaction media (the 6th cycle). Thus, we can observe a change in the morphology and a decrease in dispersity after re-use of the catalyst. The change in all parameters of Table 3 means that the number of W atoms promoted by Ni on the faces, edges and corners of the crystallites decreases from the 1 st to the 5th cycles, which correlates to the decrease in the activity of the catalyst. The composition of catalyst surface after the 1 st, 5th and 6th cycles was determined by the XPS method (Table 4 and 5) . As the number of cycles increases, the carbon content on the catalyst surface slightly grows up, and it drastically increases (up to 50.6 %) after a supplementary additive of elemental sulfur is introduced (the 6th cycle). As this takes place, in spite of additional sulfurization, the content of sulfur and oxygen considerably decreases, which indicates that these elements are replaced by carbon on the catalyst surface. Data on the concentration of phases found on the catalyst surface, calculated after the deconvolution of the spectra, are given in Table 6 . The deconvolution of the W4f level has shown that tungsten is in three states: sulfide WS2 (W4f7/2 32.4–33.4 eV; W4f5/2 34.6–35.4 eV depending from the sample in Table 6), oxysulfide WOxSy (W4f7/2 33.1–33.8 eV; W4f5/2 35.5–36.1 eV) and oxide WO3 (W4f7/2 36.8–37.4 eV; W4f5/2 38.2–39.0 eV) [37], with a considerable preponderance of the sulfide form. A similar situation is observed for nickel that is present on the surface in three states: as the sulfide NiSx (Ni2p3/2 852.7–853.8 eV; Ni2p1/2 869.5–870.5 eV), Ni-W-S (Ni2p3/2 853.4–854.5 eV; Ni2p1/2 870.7–871.6 eV) and NiO (Ni2p3/2 855.9–856.4 eV; Ni2p1/2 873.8–874.3 eV) [38,39], also with a considerable preponderance of the sulfide form. As a result of the deconvolution of the S2p level, it has been ascertained that sulfur is present predominantly (about 90 %) in the form of sulfide S2− (S2p3/2 162.4–163.0 eV; S2p1/2 163.6–164.1 eV), and also in the form of S2 2- (S2p3/2 165.7–165.3 eV; S2p1/2 165.9–167.4 eV) and SO4 2- (S2p3/2 167.4 eV; S2p1/2 168.3 eV just for NiWS-tfs (5) sample) [40]. As can be seen from Table 6, a certain decrease in the content of tungsten sulfide can be observed with an increase in the number of cycles. A substantially different pattern is observed for nickel: the NiSx nickel sulfide content increasces considerably (from 9.6–56.4%) upon transition from the first to fifth cycle, and then again drastically increases up to 64.1 % after the sixth cycle of naphthalene hydrogenation. Meanwhile, a directly opposite dependence is observed for the Ni-W-S phase. Obviously, this very fact is indicative of the reduction in catalytic activity (reduction in the decalin selectivity) upon re-use of the catalyst. This means that the content of the nickel phase increases and the content of the Ni–W–S phase decreases. Using data on the elemental composition of the surface of the catalyst NiWS-tfs (Table 4) and the content of phases (Table 5), the absolute content of WS2 and Ni–W–S phases, as well as the degree of promotion of WS2 crystallites by Nickel (Table 6) was found. Table 6 shows that the absolute content of the Ni–W–S phase is higher after the 1 st cycle than after the 5th. The addition of sulfur increases the absolute content of the Ni–W–S phase and the degree of promotion (6th cycle). These changes correlate with a decrease in dispersion and reduction of catalytic activity (reduction of decalin selectivity) when the catalyst is reused. 3.8 Hydrogenation of bicyclic aromatic HCs with methyl substituents In this paper, we also studied hydrogenation of methyl-substituted naphthalenes. In this case, changes in the catalytic activity and conversion products composition are expected. Now, this takes place due to the influence of electron-donor substituents on the electron density of methylnaphthalenes and the displacement of equilibrium towards formation of adsorption complex during substrate adsorption. On the other hand, the presence of substituents in the aromatic ring can result in steric hindrances during the adsorption of methylnaphthalenes, which interferes with reaction behavior and leads to a decrease in the catalytic activity. The hydrogenation of bicyclic aromatic hydrocarbons with a methyl substituent in the presence of [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 was examined using the example of 1-methylnaphthalene and 2-methylnaphthalene (Scheme 1 ). A 10 % hydrocarbon solution in n-hexadecane was used as the model feedstock; the substrate to tungsten ratio was 105.3:1 and the reaction time was 5 h. As can be seen from Table 7 , the conversion of methylnaphthalenes differs insignificantly and reaches 98.3 % and 99.0 % for 1- and 2-methylnaphthalene, respectively. In both cases, the main reaction products are tetralins, while the share of decalins in the reaction products does not exceed 30.0 %. In case of 1-methylnaphthalene hydrogenation, the main reaction product is 5-methyltetralin; in case of 2-methylnaphthalene hydrogenation, 6-methyltetralin. The ratio between cis- and trans-decalins is different and equals 1:2.4 in case of 1-methylnaphthalene hydrogenation and 1:3.2 in case of 2-methylnaphthalene hydrogenation. This suggests that the hydrogenation rate of the unsubstituted ring is higher than that of the ring with the methyl substituent. The reason for different hydrogenation rates of methylnaphthalene aromatic rings consists in steric hindrances during the adsorption of the methyl-substituted ring, which is consistent with the literature data [40,41]. It should be noted that not only hydrogenation products, but also methyl substituent migration products are observed as a result of methylnaphthalene conversion: 2- and 6-methyltetralins are formed during the hydrogenation of 1-methylnaphthalene and 1- and 5-methyltetralins are formed during the hydrogenation of 2-methylnaphthalene, which is also consistent with the literature data [43]. The formation of methyldecalins during the hydrogenation of 1- and 2-methylnaphthalenes (1-mn and 2-mn) in the presence of NiWS-tfs also differs insignificantly (27.1 % and 25.3 %, respectively) and the same pattern is observed for the NiWS-bmp and NiWS-wsp catalysts [18,19]. 1-methyldecalins form four stereoisomers: trans-anti-, trans-syn-, cis-anti- and cis-syn-1-methyldecalins [42]. The migration of the methyl substituent leads to another four forms of 2-methyldecalin: trans-syn-, trans-anti-, cis-syn-, and cis-anti-2-methyldecalins. Among the 1-methyldecalin isomers, trans-anti-1-methyldecalin, whose content in the reaction products is 9.4 %, exhibits the highest thermodynamic stability. Four stereoisomers of 2-methyldecalin are also formed during the hydrogenation of 2-methylnaphthalene; the migration of the methyl substituent also leads to the formation of another four stereoisomers of 1-methyldecalin. In this case, trans-syn-2-methyldecalin is the main product as the most thermodynamically stable stereoisomer. The content of this stereoisomer in the total amount of methyldecalins is 12.6 %. The fact that the hydrogenation rates of 1-methylnaphthalene and 2-methylnaphthalene are little different from each other in the presence of NiWS-tfs is not consistent with the literature data, according to which the hydrogenation rate of 2-methylnaphthalene on Pt and Pd is higher than that of 1-methylnaphthalene [42]. The reverse pattern is observed in the presence of the NiWS-bmp catalyst: the hydrogenation rate of 1-methylnaphthalene is somewhat higher than that of 2-methylnaphthalene [18]. This feature of the hydrogenation of methylnaphthalenes can also be explained by the high dispersion of NiWS-tfs [44]. The accessibility of the edges and corners of the catalyst crystallites provides less steric stress compared to a flat surface. With increasing dispersion, the number of active centers on the edges and corners increases. Therefore, the activity in the hydrogenation of 1- and 2-methylnaphthalene differs slightly. In general, the decalin selectivity is lower than for naphthalene hydrogenation, which is indicative of reduced catalytic activity in case of the hydrogenation of substituted hydrocarbons. 4 Conclusion This paper presents the results of studying the structure and properties of the [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 precursor and a catalyst on its basis obtained in situ in the reaction medium. The studied catalyst has proved to be highly active with respect to hydrogenation of naphthalene and methyl-substituted naphthalenes, and demonstrated the maximum decalin selectivity as compared to the systems studied earlier. The [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2-based catalyst was studied by the X-ray diffraction, X-ray absorption, XPS, and TEM methods. The X-ray phase analysis together with TEM and XAFS methods have shown that the studied catalysts contain the WS2 tungsten sulfide partly intercalated by nickel and nearly amorphous Ni9S8-related nickel sulfide species. Nickel atoms in the insertion compound are located between the WS2 layers in the square-planar surrounding of sulfur atoms, which is similar to that found in [Ni(WS4)2]2− anions. The detected WS2 and Ni insertion compound makes considerable changes in the structure of active sites of the tungsten sulfide-based catalysts. The structure of active sites is determined not only by nickel located near the WS2 edge atoms, but also by nickel inserted between the tungsten sulfide layers. As the amount of inserted nickel increases, the distance between the WS2 layers may change, which will affect the parameters of active sites and catalytic properties. coredata.dc:description: The unsupported NiWS-catalyst was obtained from the precursor [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 in a hydrocarbon medium (in situ) for hydrogenation bicyclic aromatic compounds. The precursor [Ph3S]2Ni(WS4)2 and the catalyst prepared on its basis were studied by the X-ray diffraction and X-ray absorption methods, XPS and TEM. It was found that the new catalyst formed in situ contains tungsten sulfide and nickel sulfide nanophases. Tungsten sulfide, which has a layered structure, partially forms an insertion compound with nickel that enters between the WS2 layers and bonds covalently to sulfur. The proposed catalyst has proved to be active in the hydrodearomatization processes of model aromatic compounds (naphthalene, methylnaphthalenes) and exhibited the maximum selectivity with the formation of decalins compared to other earlier studied catalysts formed from other precursors in the reaction medium.
coredata.dc:title: A new precursor for synthesis of nickel-tungsten sulfide aromatic hydrogenation catalyst
